clinical_notes.content: Patient admitted with septic shock secondary to pneumonia. Initial vitals: BP 85/45, HR 120, RR 28, SpO2 88% on 6L NC. ABG: pH 7.25, PaCO2 45, PaO2 65, HCO3 18, lactate 4.2. Started on norepinephrine 0.1 mcg/kg/min, fluid resuscitation with crystalloids. SOFA score 8. Meeting sepsis-3 criteria with organ dysfunction.

Patient requiring intubation due to worsening respiratory failure. ARDS criteria met: bilateral infiltrates, PaO2/FiO2 ratio 180. Ventilator settings: AC mode, TV 6 mL/kg PBW (420 mL), PEEP 10, FiO2 0.6, RR 20. Plateau pressure 28 cmH2O. Permissive hypercapnia with pH 7.22 acceptable. Started on propofol sedation, fentanyl analgesia.

Overnight course stable. Hemodynamics improved with MAP 70 mmHg on norepinephrine 0.05 mcg/kg/min. ABG: pH 7.28, PaCO2 52, PaO2 85, HCO3 24. Lactate down to 2.1. Ventilator settings adjusted: PEEP increased to 12, FiO2 decreased to 0.5. PaO2/FiO2 ratio 170. Consider prone positioning if no improvement in 24 hours.

Patient transferred from OR after emergency laparotomy for perforated diverticulitis. Post-op course complicated by acute respiratory failure. ABG: pH 7.18, PaCO2 58, PaO2 72, HCO3 21. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. Started on BiPAP initially, but required intubation due to worsening hypercapnia and altered mental status.

Intubated and mechanically ventilated. Settings: SIMV mode, TV 8 mL/kg, PEEP 5, FiO2 0.4, RR 16. Plateau pressure 25 cmH2O. Hemodynamically stable, no vasopressors needed. Started on propofol 25 mcg/kg/min, fentanyl 50 mcg/hr. RASS -2. Plan for daily sedation interruption and SBT tomorrow if stable.

Patient with STEMI, anterior wall, underwent primary PCI with drug-eluting stent to LAD. Post-procedure complicated by cardiogenic shock. Echo: EF 25%, severe global hypokinesis. Hemodynamics: MAP 55 mmHg, CVP 18 mmHg, cardiac index 1.8 L/min/m². Started on dobutamine 5 mcg/kg/min and norepinephrine 0.1 mcg/kg/min. IABP considered if no improvement.

Hemodynamics improved with inotropic support. Current MAP 68 mmHg, CVP 12 mmHg. Dobutamine increased to 7.5 mcg/kg/min. Norepinephrine weaned to 0.05 mcg/kg/min. Cardiac index improved to 2.2 L/min/m². Urine output adequate at 1.2 mL/kg/hr. Plan to wean vasopressors gradually over next 24-48 hours.

Patient with DKA, type 1 diabetes. Initial presentation: altered mental status, Kussmaul respirations, fruity breath odor. Labs: glucose 650 mg/dL, pH 6.95, HCO3 5, anion gap 28, ketones positive. Severe metabolic acidosis requiring ICU monitoring. Started on insulin drip 0.1 units/kg/hr, aggressive fluid resuscitation with normal saline.

Overnight improvement in acidosis. Repeat ABG: pH 7.15, HCO3 12, anion gap 18. Glucose down to 280 mg/dL. Insulin drip continued at 0.05 units/kg/hr. Potassium supplementation needed due to intracellular shift. Patient more alert, Kussmaul respirations resolved. Plan to transition to subcutaneous insulin when anion gap closes and patient eating.
